body:
The -Qualifier code for Split-Path made some incorrect assumptions:
- That a path only referred to the file system
- That drives cannot be used on Unix systems

These assumptions were both wrong, so I've reverted the change so we
do not have any Unix specific code in Split-Path now.

Fixes #1176

body:
# Overview

This is a work-in-progress list of features that have been investigated and determined to not require modification for side-by-side scenarios. I am creating this issue to document the list and reasoning behind the decisions.
# Pwrshsip.dll

This is the Crypto Subject Interface Package (SIP) provider for handling Authenticode signature verification for all signed files PowerShell supports (psd1, psm1, etc.). The provider is loaded by the Authenticode verification system and only one instance should exist in Windows. It is installed via manifest on all Windows SKUs where PowerShell ships inbox. If we need to add additional file types for Authenticode signature verification, we can create a new SIP provider and install it side-by-side with the existing one. The new provider will only support the new file types.

On Windows, the PowerShell installer will not automatically enable receiving incoming requests. The feature shall be activated as a post-install step that requires Administrator-level authorization (due to the WinRM plugin's System32 placement requirement).
# Changes Required

Cmdlet implementation should be changed to also 
1. Copy pwrshplugin.dll from %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<versionX>\ (aka $PSHOME) to %windir%\System32\PowerShell<versionX>
2. Create a the necessary plugin configuration file in %windir%\System32\PowerShell<versionX>
3. Register the plugin as a WinRM endpoint (Proposed name = PowerShell.<versionX>)

Get-PSSessionConfiguration should work with these changes.

body:
# Overview

PowerShell Core for Windows should support a common launcher that can start either a specified version of or a "default" version .
# Changes Required
1. An executable or script that supports a -version <version> parameter and passes cmd line arguments to an instance of PowerShell.exe
2. The executable or script resides is %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell\powershell.exe
3. It determines the "default" instance of PowerShell by reading a value from a configuration file in its same directory. File type and format are flexible and should be driven by the ease of parsing the info.
# Open Issues
1. The exact design has not yet been finalized. This is a place holder issue to note that work is likely required to support the desired behavior.
2. On non-Windows systems, the installer already creates a symlink on the path that points to the latest installed instance of PowerShell. No additional work is likely required in those environments.

body:
# Overview

PowerShell's WinRM plugin must reside in a directory under %windir%\System32 due to a WinRM security restriction. Since the plugin cannot be in the same directory as PowerShell, the plugin needs to detect which instance of PowerShell it should load. 
# Changes Required

The plugin shall be modified to support starting PowerShell from arbitrary locations. A config file shall be read to direct the plugin to the appropriate version of CoreCLR and PowerShell that it should load into its process. The exact file format and contents are up to us. A simple text file with KEY=VALUE pairs should be sufficient.
## Configuration file contents:
1. PSHOMEDIR - Points to the plugin's PSHome (SMA.dll directory)
2. CORECLRDIR - Points to the instance's CoreCLR

body:
# Overview

It is desirable to have each instance of PowerShell log ETW events to its own instance-specific event log rather than re-using the existing inbox PowerShell event log. To do this, each instance of PowerShell must register its event manifest with ETW and carry its own copy of PSEvents.dll (assuming it differs from the inbox version of the file).
# Changes Required
1. Port PSEvents.dll to GitHub. The big step here is to create PSEvents.dll from the manifest
2. Generate a unique GUID and name for the event provider during each major or minor release. These values must be saved in Microsoft-Windows-PowerShell-Instrumentation.man.
3. Create a post-install script or cmdlet to register the event provider with ETW using wevtutil.exe
# Open Issues:
1. wevtutil.exe should be supported on all Windows OSs, but it might now work on Nano Server. How do we support event registration in that case?
2. More investigation is required to determine the process for generating PSEvents.dll in GitHub. SD produces it automatically for us based on a macro.
3. A non-Windows eventing or logging solution should be researched as well.

body:
# Overview

In PowerShell repo, there is a need to decouple as much as possible from PowerShell's existing dependence on the Windows registry. This requirement is driven by a lack of a registry in non-Windows environments and a need to isolate side-by-side instances of PowerShell from interfering with each other's operation.
1. Two configuration file directories are needed
   1. $PSHOME\Configuration -- Holds HKLM registry values; "System-wide"
   2. SpecialFolder.LocalApplicationData -- Holds HKCU registry values; "per-user"
      - Windows = %LOCALAPPDATA%\PowerShell\Configuration
      - non-Windows = ~/.config/PowerShell/Configuration
2. Each registry key is a separate file
   1. The file name is the key and the content is the value. All values are strings or easily converted to and from strings.
   2. Preferred file format is JSON, but it may be unnecessary given one-key-per-file.
   3. Positives
      1. Mitigates multi-process reader & writer issues
      2. Allows per-file access control
   4. Negatives
      1. More files to manage
      2. May be unnecessary; no data to confirm whether it is an actual performance bottleneck
# Values Needed:
## PSModulePath

Existing Key = HKLM:\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment
Proposed value = %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell\Modules by default
## DisablePromptToUpdateHelp

Existing Key = HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\PowerShell
Proposed value = Existing default. Probably "0"
## PipeLineMaxStackSizeMB

Existing Key = HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\PowerShell\1\ShellIds
Proposed value = Existing default. Probably "10"
## ConsolePrompting

Existing Key = HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\PowerShell\1\ShellIds
Proposed value = existing default. Probably "1"
## ExecutionPolicy

Existing Key = HKCU and HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\PowerShell\1\ShellIds\Microsoft.PowerShell
Proposed value = existing default execution policy
## DefaultSourcePath

Existing Key = HKCU and HKLM\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\PowerShell\UpdatableHelp
Proposed value = blank. This should be supported though
### Note: Storage of machine-level and user-level environment variables is still an open topic. We can store them in files, but we might want to leave them as-is (written to registry) in Windows.
# Tasks
- [x] Merge portions of the prototype code and add it to the build
- [x] Write new class for reading from and writing to JSON files
- [x] Replace calls within PS code to use the new interface
- [ ] Write tests and verify functionality

body:
PowerShell requires a new module path that points to PowerShell Core modules rather than inbox PowerShell modules.

Desired values and order:
1. ~\Documents\PowerShell\Modules - User documents module location for PowerShell Core
2. %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell\Modules - Common module path for all instances of PowerShell Core
3. %ProgramFiles%\PowerShell<version>\Modules - Module path for the specific instance of PowerShell Core that is running.

PowerShell on Linux will need similar values, as described inline.

body:
This list captures all places where we expose some secrets that we need to clean-up and instructions to do that
## Instruction
- In incognito mode, login to powershell-ci account on github.
- In another tab, login into ci.appveyor.com with GitHub + PowerShell
#### AppVeyor
- [x] Change password for **AppVeyor** for powershell-ci. Use https://ci.appveyor.com/change-password
- [x] This account is from [nuget.config](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/2856103fa51b44357cbf5df9fc1c2cf97eaf6b57/nuget.config#L20). Remove it from the code (but not from the history)
#### Travis CI
- [x] Remove token from script (it was intorduced in #1406). It leaves in [download.sh](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/1d8a181f607d8c3482feec71cf7b0ac77cf7551d/tools/download.sh#L3) now.
- [x] Rewrite `download.sh` to stop using API and thus requiring token
#### GitHub
- [x] Wipe ssh-keys for submodules from build servers on https://github.com/settings/keys page
- [x] Revokepersonal access tokens
- [x] Remove the call to decrypt the key from [appveyor.yml](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/2856103fa51b44357cbf5df9fc1c2cf97eaf6b57/appveyor.yml#L17)  (but not from the history)
# Action sequence
- Before repo is public, #1160
- Opening the repo
- Shortly after (or before, doesn't matter) #1610 and #1553

body:
We only use the submodule for nuget feed.
This change uses appveyor-hosted nuget feed from the same repo, instead of a submodule version.
If you need to add a new package, just push it in https://github.com/PowerShell/psl-windows-build/tree/master/nuget-feed

When this change is merged, issue to change password on CI account should be opened, because currently we expose a clear-text password (secure password doesn't work on Linux for dotnet cli at the moment).
title: Remove src/windows-build submodule

This is left-over from #1148 

We are building pwrshplugin.dll for FullCLR build, but we need it for Nano server as well.
Nano server is a little bit trickier, because it requires installing of https://developer.microsoft.com/en-US/windows/downloads/windows-10-sdk
## Message Compiler

We use **mc.exe** for Full build to compile native resources and it fails in CI
https://ci.appveyor.com/project/PowerShell/powershell/build/0.4.0.2558#L206 (this is build from master)

There are two problems:
- [x] Fix the failure
- [x] Find out why it didn't fail the build and fix this: such errors must fail the build: **Answer:** because I didn't use `Start-NativeExecution` helper function.

body:
Per #1081, we have the known issue of not supporting a path with a literal backward slash for PowerShell cmdlets. This [branch](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/tree/andschwa/path-normalization) is work-in-progress that investigated PowerShell's path normalization.

The summary is that it's a mess. PowerShell has half a dozen different path normalization functions (all essentially just blindly replacing `/` with `\`, or the reverse on Linux), another dozen locations where these are ignored and a `path.Replace()` is done, and completely separate code to handle escape character parsing (which is tied into the globbing system); and all of this is spread across several systems.

My WIP branch removes all the normalization functions and adds some (dumb, so far) logic to handle a path with a backtick escaped backward slash (but it needs to be improved to handle backtick escaped backticks). Normalization of all backticks can only happen once, and we need to figure out how to make this happen, because parsing globs must be handled around the same time (since glob characters may be escaped). As of now, the WIP does allow escaping a backward slash with a backtick.

This issue is an extension of #570 and #954.

``` powershell
echo hi
```


On linux, this should work even if the extension isn't `.ps1`
